annotations.paragraph: According to the 2025 World Happiness Report, which was released last month, the happiest country in the world is Finland, trailed closely by Denmark, Iceland and Sweden.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides key information about the happiest countries according to the report, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: This news came as no surprise. The report, released annually since 2012 by a consortium of groups including Gallup, often features these four Nordic nations — all of them stable democracies with prosperous and healthy citizens — at or near the top of its list. At the bottom (out of 147 countries assessed) was Afghanistan, then Sierra Leone, Lebanon and Malawi.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context and background on the report's history and the countries typically featured, which is relevant to understanding the main story.

annotations.paragraph: These rankings reinforce a key supposition of our globalized political and economic order: Poor countries are unhappy because they are poor, and wealth is a critical precondition for individual and societal flourishing. The International Monetary Fund encourages trade and economic growth on the theory that happiness increases with material prosperity. Political thinkers such as Francis Fukuyama and Steven Pinker talk about wanting to help poor and turbulent nations “get to Denmark.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context and commentary on the assumptions about wealth and happiness, relevant to the discussion of the happiest country.
